instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
Board was little liquid damage <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> area cleaning and replace corroded components,

Good charger know, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 2.9V and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.22V already check <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area

Noticed voltage on F6905 20V is not too high ? red area in picture heat  [ATTACH type="full" width="60%"]32066._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
The first thing is why is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 2.9v instead of 3.425v? That isn't right at all.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> being 12.23v means the SMC is not running. Is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.42v? Does the SMC seem corroded? What is diode mode on pin 2 of on <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR>, with red probe on ground?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V

diode mode on pin2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> 0,480V

<RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> 0,483V 

smc seem clean no corroded

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
Well first you need to get <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to be 3.42v before anything else will work, so let's focus on that. 

With an original 85w charger plugged in:

1) What voltage do you get at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR>? 
2) What voltage do you get at pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR>?
3) What voltage do you get at pin 8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>?

IF you get anything less than 16v at any of these points, remove power from the meter and measure:

1) What is resistance to ground at pin 6 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>?
2) What is resistance to ground at pin 2 of L6995?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
Voltage pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> 20,5V pin 2 15,20V

pin 8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> 14,78V

pin 2 of L6995 124,7 ohms
pin 6 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> 10mohms and decrease

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
Can you use a decimal point instead of a comma for voltages? You're making my eyes bleed reading that.

It seems like there is a short circuit on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. This will be difficult to find because at 124 ohms it will only use up something like 0.1 watts which will produce virtually no heat at all. Your job here is to inject 3.42v into <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and find what gets hot, but without some sort of expensive thermal camera or freeze spray that will be very difficult to do.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
sorry for your eyes ;)

so pin 2 of L6995 i've 124 Kohms sorry

removed L6995 inject 3.4V on pin 2 i've got 0.47 amps and smc heat (already replace same probl√®m)

noticed with magsafe plugged same problem smc heat

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
This is a discrepancy in measurements.

On one hand, the SMC is getting hot and it is taking 0.47 amps on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.

On the other hand, there is 124000 ohms to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.

It is highly unlikely these two can both be true at the same time. You said earlier that <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> had 124 ohms to ground, and that makes far more sense when combined with the rest of the available information. This is supported by the fact that the SMC gets hot.

However, you have also said that replacing the SMC does not fix the issue of the SMC getting hot. This makes absolutely no sense and brings us back to square one, unless you are replacing it with other bad SMCs, or soldering it very improperly, which is possible.

I would remove the SMC and see how many amps <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is using without the SMC. Wick the pads so no residual solder is causing a short. With the SMC removed, how many amps are pulled injecting 3.42v into <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message: removed smc, injected 3.42V into <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and i get 0.05 amps

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message:
Ok, we're getting somewhere. So short circuit present with SMC on, short circuit gone with SMC off. 

One of two things is possible:

1) You put on another bad SMC.
2) The SMC you put on was good but you used too much heat removing it from the old board/reballing/soldering it onto the new board. 

So I would say find another SMC and put it on there.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green/orange light
threads.message: find 2 bad capacitor around smc, <CAPACITOR>C4903</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4916</CAPACITOR> (corroded) thanks for your help solved
